content.headline: Abuse victims say inquiry must continue after chair's resignation

supporting.headline: 'One in 14 adults sexually abused in childhood'

supporting.headline: Sex education is the only way to combat child abuse
supporting.trailText: In the post-Savile era ministers blocked the one step that can protect young people. Help me make PSHE – personal, social and health education – compulsory

content.headline: Black Lives Matter protest sparks traffic chaos outside airport
content.trailText: Protesters block road near London airport, halting M4 traffic, as similar action is seen in Nottingham and Birmingham

supporting.trailText: Officials say man who fought off attacker near Olympic park does not work for embassy amid reports he used fake papers

content.headline: Cargo plane crashes onto road after overshooting runway
content.trailText: The cargo plane, a Boeing 737 belonging to DHL couriers, crashed after landing in apparent bad weather

content.headline: Scottish aristocrat's son innocent of cocaine smuggling, says family

content.trailText: Party concedes defeat in Port Elizabeth and could lose control of Johannesburg and Pretoria

supporting.headline: Osborne and Tory donors on list

content.headline: Bank blames £2bn half-year loss on string of legal challenges

content.headline: American victim Darlene Horton was an inspiration, friends say
content.trailText: Darlene Horton, a retired teacher, was highly regarded in her Florida community for her ‘vibrant personality’ and philanthropy

content.headline: Actor who played The Big Lebowski dies at 85
content.trailText: The actor, most recognised for the cult Coens comedy, had also starred in Santa Claus: The Movie, Blazing Saddles and Frantic

content.headline: Your underwhelming British holiday photos
content.trailText: The weather looks to be improving, so these pictures of our holidaying readers should make you feel better about things

content.headline: The chain pushing to bring home cinema to the high street
content.trailText: Boutique company buying up empty Odeons and former ‘picture houses’ to give film-goers a G&T on the sofa-style experience

content.headline: England v Pakistan – third Test, day three

supporting.headline: Ali puts Pakistan in control with superb century
supporting.trailText: Azhar Ali was dismissed with the final ball of the day for 139 but Pakistan trail England by only 40 runs with seven first-innings wickets remaining in the third Test

content.headline: Facing my fear: driving while black can be fatal. But I've got places to go
content.trailText: A traffic stop could easily escalate and end my life. It happens to black drivers in America all the time

content.headline: Google is trying to stop you having to put in passwords
content.trailText: New open source project hopes to remove burden of remembering passwords and instantly log you into apps on Android, with plans to roll out across every platform

content.headline: McDonald's wants us to size up its 'food journey' – so let's do that
content.trailText: Does it think we have forgotten the calorific dressed salad or ammonia-infused ‘pink slurry’?

content.headline: 18 reasons why you can’t miss the fringe
content.trailText: Think it’s just about the jokes? From weight loss to mind expansion, our panel of comedians reveal the hidden perks  of a trip to the festival

supporting.headline: Three shows to see today
supporting.trailText: At the fringe but not sure which tickets to book? Try one, two or all three of these picks from our critics

content.headline: Fela was right – but I detest singing militant
content.trailText: After pioneering afrobeat in the 70s, Tony Allen has gone on to work with musicians as diverse as Damon Albarn and Flea. As part of our series Gateways – Tony Allen and Nigeria, in association with Boiler Room, he talks about Fela Kuti, drugs and the art of drumming

content.headline: The real story of the Secret Agent and the Greenwich bombing
content.trailText: The bombing in Greenwich Park described in Conrad’s Secret Agent was inspired by real events. Was the Royal Observatory the intended target and, if so, why?

content.headline: Jokes, tank-tops and Delia Smith
content.trailText: Never mind Margaret Thatcher, it was the famous chef who embodied the values of the decade, according to this bold and cheerful history lesson. Plus Mo Farah: Race of his Life

content.headline: The new wave of tech troops outraged at Trump's remarks
content.trailText: After Donald Trump’s call on Russia to hack the Democratic nominee, an atypical fundraiser proved popular at the Black Hat hackers conference

content.headline: What touring with Wild Beasts taught me about cities
content.trailText: Wild Beasts bassist Tom Fleming examines the strange experience of visiting cities on tour, from Tokyo to Dallas to São Paulo

content.headline: The race to save decades of work saved on obsolete technology
content.trailText: Archivists trying to preserve material stored on old computers by Australian writer and feminist Germaine Greer

content.headline: Things take on a different meaning when death comes so close
content.trailText: The actor best known as Parks and Recreation’s April Ludgate talks about her new film, Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates – and the stroke she suffered aged 20

content.headline: An important, even-handed documentary
content.trailText: Brendan J Byrne’s film makes the case that Sands's 1981 hunger strike led to the Good Friday agreement

content.headline: What attracted Kate Moss and Fergie to holiday on a billionaire’s yacht?
content.trailText: The model and the Duchess of York have been spotted together on David Tang’s boat. It’s like a cruise for chronic suckers-up to the wealthy

content.headline: Brains of overweight people look 10 years older than those of lean peers
content.trailText: Scans show greater shrinkage in volume of white matter in overweight and obese people, although it does not appear to affect cognitive performance

content.headline: 'I did snake therapy – I had to carry around a rubber snake in my bag'
content.trailText: Her new horror movie Lights Out is terrifying – but the actor insists she’s not a fan of blood and gore, and is more afraid of snakes than the supernatural

content.headline: Gooseberry tart from Swallows and Amazons
content.trailText: While enjoying British summer holidays, Kate Young was taken back to her childhood dreams to live in Arthur Ransome’s adventure stories

content.headline: From Bowie to grime lords, the Mercury list revives an ailing brand
content.trailText: In recent years the Mercury shortlist has been boring. This year the judges have rectified this with a list that includes Bowie, Radiohead and Skepta

content.headline: For people who like a nice way of living, with picnics
content.trailText: Surprise TV sensation begins foray into live events with four-day show in grounds of Blenheim Palace in Oxfordshire

content.headline: Gay characters are there, but only just
content.trailText: While LGBT characters have appeared in blockbusters, fears of a backlash from older cinemagoers, and overseas audiences, keep them largely in the closet

content.headline: Michelin star for noodle stall where lunch is half the price of a Big Mac
content.trailText: Queues at Hong Kong Soya Sauce Chicken Rice and Noodle are growing after award from prestigious food guide

content.headline: What forms our tastes in a digital age?
content.trailText: Why do we like what we like – this band or that ice-cream flavour? Is it biological or cultural? And what role do Amazon and Netflix play in shaping our preferences?

content.headline: Is this Europe's best secret museum?
content.trailText: In a small German town, a museum dedicated to life in the GDR – with everything from crank-handled calculators to Communist doilies – exists, virtually undiscovered, in one man’s attic

content.headline: A beautiful upgrade, but only for 4K fanatics
content.trailText: Microsoft’s first major upgrade to console offers a sleek new chassis and 4K Ultra HD features – but do you need them?

content.headline: Bolshoi's furiously funny battle of the sexes

content.headline: How 70 years of TV socially engineered the perfect family
content.trailText: From Ask the Family’s stereotypical 1950s unit to today’s nagging nannies, television has long used families to structure its programmes. But do these shows reflect ever-changing norms, or are they designed to shape society itself?

content.headline: Sun-drenched recipes inspired by Crete
content.trailText: Redolent tomatoes straight from the vine, anchovies fresh from the water, herbs picked on the hillside ... Cretan food is a lively intertwining of the earth and sea, exemplified here by three sun-drenched dishes

content.headline: Never ever fall out with the nurses
content.trailText: Ask questions, tidy up ... and listen to the nurses are among top tips healthcare professionals share with new doctors

content.headline: How to make the perfect caprese salad
content.trailText: Surely, you cry, no one can go wrong arranging tomatoes, basil and mozzarella on a plate. Well, they can and they do – so here’s how to make a faultless version of this high-summer salad

content.headline: Three elderly women go to Amsterdam to try out the hash
content.trailText: Despite a combined age of 233, some space cake seems to do the trick, and they head off to play on the swings. Plus Gogglebox: Brexit Special provides some insightful comments about our politicians

content.headline: When do the Olympics start and how can I follow the action?

content.headline: Athletes’ Olympic spirit is only hope of redeeming the sullied Games
content.trailText: Like their host city, the Olympics stand at a crossroads and local apathy has been compounded by the recent Russian doping revelations

content.headline: Neymar and Brazil draw blank in opener with South Africa
content.trailText: Brazil were held to a goalless draw by South Africa in their first men’s football match of Rio 2016

content.trailText: The sprinter, who has settled in Australia, says permanently quitting the sport ‘appears the only option’

content.headline: Some women may reject top jobs – but many men don’t want them either

content.headline: It’s time fiction reflected gay married life
content.trailText: Attitudes towards commitment in gay relationships have changed – the novel could help to define them

content.headline: It’s five years since the English riots, but the rifts in society are wider than ever

content.headline: Want to avoid recession? Then shower UK households with cash

content.headline: Those who deny the housing crisis can no longer conceal their idiocy
content.trailText: With each damning housing report, the dinosaurs who refuse to acknowledge facts peel off

content.headline: If peers apply the brakes to Brexit, we’ll be doing our job
content.trailText: It’s not our role to defy the will of the people. But faced with potential calamity, we can ask the government to think again

content.headline: A digital detox sounds great. But using the internet mindfully is better
content.trailText: Like many young people, I live much of my life online. While it can be isolating, the internet can also aid mental health

content.headline: Labour can fight for working people without dumping progressive ideas
content.trailText: Facing a schism after the shock of Brexit, the party must continue to work for its traditional base

content.headline: Martin Rowson on state of the UK economy
content.trailText: The Bank of England has cut interest rates to a new record low of 0.25% from 0.5% in a package of measures designed to prevent a post-Brexit recession

content.headline: We fixate on the Ukip pantomime. That’s a serious mistake
content.trailText: Its Brexit campaign was deeply deceitful – but supporters of the real nasty party have grievances that mainstream politicians should listen to

content.headline: Violence against lone child refugees is escalating – because we ignore it
content.trailText: Police violence, citizen violence, camp violence – abuse in the Calais and Dunkirk camps has many forms. But UK government indifference does so much more damage

content.headline: Thank you, President Obama, for being a feminist
content.trailText: In an essay for Glamour, Barack Obama wrote about how gender stereotypes harm us all. It was a radical act – and one that makes us miss him already

content.headline: Trump’s greatest feat: making Reagan and Bush seem like good guys
content.trailText: When the Democrats can point to old-time Republicans as virtuous examples, you know that something has gone terribly wrong

content.headline: The Daily Mail’s PrEP story was like going back to the dark old days of the 80s

content.headline: How legitimate marriages have become Home Office honey traps
content.trailText: Loose canon: The administration of marriage has been taken out of the hands of the church – and used as a crude tool for the state to carry out deportations

content.headline: Interest rate cut is a 'hammer blow' for workplace pensions

content.headline: My advice to Ed Balls on Strictly? Just follow my lead

content.headline: It’s the summer holidays – and children need time outside
content.trailText: Britain’s children face both an obesity epidemic and a mental health crisis. Giving them the chance to be active and connect with nature can only help

content.headline: Why has Britain stopped striking? Workers no longer feel empowered to act

content.headline: Granting this licence to shoot buzzards will unleash a killing spree

content.headline: Don’t ‘diagnose’ Donald Trump, it’s not helpful
content.trailText: Calls for Donald Trump to undergo psychiatric assessment may mean well, but will do more harm than good.

content.headline: Audio-fail: why is so much sound art so bad?

content.headline: Young Chekhov is the greatest of theatrical marathons

content.headline: No9: Liverpool

supporting.headline: Paul Doyle on Leicester City
supporting.trailText: Written off already by many, Claudio Ranieri’s side is still strong and now he has a full squad to tinker with – youth, new signings and a strong start will be key

content.headline: What lies ahead this season?

There’s an almighty stand-off that’s going to play out over the next nine months, but who will ride away into the sunset victorious?

content.headline: Trump, you have sacrificed nothing

content.headline: Users tend to have lower self-esteem, research shows

content.headline: Peru president leads ministerial gym class in front of palace
content.trailText: Newly elected elected leader Pedro Pablo Kuczynski joins 11 ministers for workout following questions about his health

content.headline: Apple offers up to $200,000 reward for finding security bugs
content.trailText: The top prize will be given for finding bugs in Apple’s ‘secure boot’ firmware for blocking unwanted programs when an iOS device powers up

content.headline: Scientists edge closer to creating effective Zika virus vaccine
content.trailText: Successful short-term trials of three different vaccine formulations boost confidence that a viable human vaccine is on the horizon

content.headline: Pollution may shorten lung cancer patients' lives, research shows
content.trailText: American study of people with early-stage disease adds to evicence about health impact of airborne toxins

supporting.headline: Genes linked to rare cancer affecting children and young adults uncovered
supporting.trailText: Sarcomas disproportionately affect the young, but researchers have discovered a host of genes linked to the cancers, raising hopes for better treatment

content.headline: Head of Isis in Egypt killed by security forces
content.trailText: Abu Duaa al-Ansari was killed with at least 45 other jihadis in an operation involving Egypt’s air force and anti-terrorism squad, according to army

content.headline: Death toll from Nice truck attack rises to 85 after man dies of injuries
content.trailText: 56-year-old, who has been on life support since tragedy, died on Thursday in a hospital in the French city

content.headline: Military veterans demand Republicans unendorse Trump and his 'ignorance'
content.trailText: Group of veterans visit Capitol Hill to present petition to Senator John McCain urging him and other Republican leaders to disavow presidential nominee

supporting.headline: Melania Trump denies she unlawfully worked as model on improper visa
supporting.trailText: The New York Post published naked photos taken of Donald Trump’s wife in 1995, a year before she emigrated to the US, according to previous statements

content.headline: Judge orders arrest of Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo leader
content.trailText: Hundreds of protesters impeded police efforts to arrest Hebe de Bonafini for refusing to appear for questioning in case of alleged embezzlement

content.headline: Israel accuses Gaza director of diverting cash to Hamas
content.trailText: Charity defends Mohammad El Halabi, who Israeli security forces say confessed during detention to being Hamas member

content.headline: A blind student's guide to choosing a campus
content.trailText: Can you get the bus to campus? Are electronic books available? Here are the main things to consider before you apply

content.headline: Billie Piper gives a breathtakingly uninhibited performance in Yerma
content.trailText: In a bravura display, Piper lays bare the soul of a woman who is unable to have children – even if Simon Stone’s update is less powerful than Lorca’s original play

content.headline: Popular dog name or popular baby name?

content.headline: Pokémon Go jumps the shark from virtual to reality

supporting.trailText: Here are six easy steps to rid yourself of Pokémon Go for good. Follow them all

content.headline: A hilarious sitcom about terrible people and broken lives

content.trailText: Whether you’re on holiday or just by the local pool, you can make a splash in a stylish one-piece

content.headline: (And you won't believe how they're doing it!)

content.trailText: Magical wooden wonderlands and blooming marvellous sheds; luxuriantly photographed wildlife through the seasons; and the Olympics opening ceremony

content.trailText: This 30th anniversary restoration of Alex Cox’s Beckettian masterpiece shows how punk camouflaged a lot of undiagnosed dysfunction

content.headline: Morrissey talks about Galloway, Farage and Sadiq Khan

content.headline: Swipe right for negative self perception, suggests research

content.trailText: The vest is making an appearance on the catwalk, on TV and on the street, but do you need a perfect upper body to carry it off?

content.headline: Eroica is voted greatest symphony of all time
content.trailText: German and Austrian composers occupy eight of top 10 places in survey of leading conductors by BBC Music magazine

content.headline: Break for the Bordeaux

content.trailText: Calvin and Hobbes provides the template for web collages putting Trump’s head onto the much loved comic strip’s juvenile hero

content.headline: Why the slasher flick works better on TV

content.headline: Henry Normal's poetic paean to his autistic son
content.trailText: Henry Normal, co-writer of The Royle Family and other comedy hits, beautifully folds in the pathos as he talks about his son who has ‘mildly severe’ autism

content.headline: Can I still upgrade from Vista to Windows 10 or should I buy a new PC?
content.trailText: Vista users need to estimate how long their PC will remain usable before they decide to upgrade, but a few loopholes exist

content.headline: How I survived the world’s least-stimulating dinner party
content.trailText: A San Francisco dining event serving only Soylent, a meal-substitute drink, asks guests to focus on each other instead of the food. But is it any fun?

content.headline: Are you defined by your job title?
content.trailText: I didn’t realise until I left my permanent role how much my job defined me – or how I would feel without it as a freelancer

content.headline: Le Corbusier and Eileen Gray at Cap Moderne
content.trailText: A peninsula near Monaco is home to an array of modernist architecture, including houses by two stars of the scene, and a revamped visitor centre is helping to show it all in the best light

content.headline: I'm buying a home for me and my girlfriend  – what happens if we split up?
content.trailText: She will contribute to the deposit and monthly mortgage payments, but I will be the sole owner

content.headline: Bright and oversized earrings
content.trailText: Giant earrings are an easy way to update your look. Think Perspex, insects and diamanté and – most importantly – the bigger the better

content.headline: Andy Zaltzman's Summer of Sport
content.trailText: Coming to you live in glorious Sport-o-scope - every week throughout summer 2016 - Andy Zaltzman and guests so special we can’t say here, give their insight into the summer’s sporting bonanza

content.headline: Secret messages, boomboxes and Boys Don't Cry

content.headline: Colin Thubron on his passion for Asia
content.trailText: The continent that ‘both invites and resists understanding’ has always fascinated the travel writer. And his favourite country is today the saddest: Syria

content.headline: How Russia spills two Deepwater Horizons of oil each year
content.trailText: Oil spills in the Komi Republic caused by old pipelines are relatively small and rarely garner widespread attention - but added up they threaten fish stocks and pasture for cattle

content.headline: Ordinary people can't afford a home in San Francisco. How did it come to this?
content.trailText: The city by the bay has the nation’s priciest real estate, and a battle is raging over whether tech wealth, population growth, or political will is to blame

content.headline: Trump, Brexit ... is New Zealand your escape route too?
content.trailText: Billy Crystal has threatened to move here if Trump wins power, and ‘move to New Zealand’ became a top Google search term after Brexit. Please consider moving here, but do so with your eyes wide open

content.headline: Fela was right – but I detest singing militant

content.headline: Big unknowns: what is consciousness?
content.trailText: What does it mean to be you? And how can science unpick the age-old debates around conscious experience? Join us for a journey into the unknown

content.headline: Hear all the albums – and see what our critics thought of them

supporting.headline: 'Mercury list revives an ailing brand'
supporting.trailText: In recent years the Mercury shortlist has committed the cardinal sin of being boring. This year the judges have rectified this with a list that includes Bowie, Radiohead and Skepta

content.headline: The doctor who convinced himself he was dying
content.trailText: When an experienced physician became convinced he had ALS, none of the specialists he consulted could persuade him he was perfectly healthy

content.headline: Africa's most innovative – and controversial – tech hacks
content.trailText: From 3D-printed limbs to hacktivists tackling oppression, Africa is the perfect place for tech innovation against the odds

content.headline: Brazilian women embrace hair's curls and kinks
content.trailText: Hair has long been a tool of political expression, and in Brazil, known for its straightening techniques, women are going natural to reclaim their racial identity

content.headline: The strange case of Marina Joyce and internet hysteria

content.headline: Positive thinking about the Middle East

content.headline: Where have all the women gone?

content.headline: How clean eating devoured the diet
content.trailText: No one can agree on what it means – and that’s because the obsession with eating ‘clean’ is less about what you put into your body and more about how you sell those choices to your followers

content.headline: Why spending more time on the internet is a good thing
content.trailText: A third of people have tried to take time offline, according to an Ofcom report, but just imagine what they’re missing …

content.headline: What it's like to ride in a driverless car

content.headline: Reparations site asks people to 'offset your privilege' with acts of kindness

content.headline: Surviving on wild seeds after failed harvests

content.headline: How a skatepark is changing the face of Yangon

content.headline: Premier League 2016-17 season preview No9: Liverpool

content.headline: McDonald's wants us to size up its 'food journey' – so let's do that
